newsitem.title: BELGIUM: FOCUS-EU forges compromise on VW subsidies row.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-EU forges compromise on VW subsidies row.

text.p: European Competition Commissioner Karel Van Miert said on Wednesday the European Commission had agreed a compromise deal over illegal subsidies paid to German carmaker Volkswagen AG.
Under the deal, Germany will freeze an amount of money due to be paid to the carmaker, neutralising illegal aid granted by the German state of Saxony.
"The Commission, therefore, will not have to take any action," Van Miert told a news conference, referring to plans to seek an interim injunction.
"At the federal level there is a commitment to freeze an amount which is equivalent or parallel to that (contested) amount."
He added, however, the Commission reserved the right to reopen the issue should Germany not respect its commitment. It could still bring an infringement case to court on the issue.
The row centred on the amount of subsidy paid to VW to build two plants in Saxony.

The Commission approved 540 million marks ($363.7 million) of a planned 780 million marks in proposed subsidies, but charged that at least 100 million marks more had been illegally handed over to the carmaker.
When the Commission objected, VW threatened to take its investment elsewhere if the subsidies did not go through.
Van Miert said on Wednesday that VW had actually received 91 million marks in illegal money.
There had been suspicions about another 16 millon marks, but German authorities had confirmed on Tuesday that the money was a legal loan granted under market conditions.
Van Miert said this meant that the German federal government would freeze 91 million marks. ($1=1.4846 Mark)
